questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because he is worried about a mole on his right forearm. He has had the mole for several years, but it has grown in size in the past 3 months. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented plaque with irregular borders and small area of ulceration. Histopathologic analysis of a full-thickness excisional biopsy confirms the diagnosis of malignant melanoma. Invasion of which of the following layers of skin carries the highest risk of mortality for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells in the stratum corneum are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to this layer are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.

B) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells extending into the reticular dermis have a high potential for metastatic spread, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

C) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells extending into the papillary dermis have metastatic potential, as the dermis contains blood and lymph vessels. However, it is not the deepest layer of the skin and invasion of a different layer of skin carries an even higher risk of mortality.

D) CORRECT:

The hypodermis (subcutis) is the deepest layer of the skin, and melanoma mortality is directly correlated with tumor thickness. Due to variability in the thickness of skin compartments among different individuals, tumor thickness does not always correspond with skin layer invasion. However, in this patient, it is likely that a tumor extending into the hypodermis is thicker than a tumor in a more superficial layer. Breslow depth is an important prognostic factor used for melanoma staging and to determine the safety margin of a wide local excision.
Image Description:

The skin is composed of the cutis (epidermis and dermis) and the subcutis.

- The epidermis has five layers: stratum corneum, lucidum, granulosum, spinosum, and basale.
- The dermis has two layers: papillary and reticular dermis.
- The subcutis contains fat and neurovascular structures.

E) INCORRECT:

Malignant cells in the stratum basale are contained within the epidermis. Tumors confined to the stratum basale are classified as a malignant melanoma in situ (MMIS) and are unlikely to metastasize, as there is no lymphovascular supply within the epidermis. The mortality rate for patients diagnosed with MMIS is low.
questions.hint: Tumor thickness is one of the most important prognostic factors for malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with chronic hepatitis C infection comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of ankle pain and nonpruritic skin lesions on his legs. He does not recall recent trauma or injury. He has not received treatment for hepatitis. Examination shows diffuse, violaceous lesions on both lower extremities. The lesions are 4–7 mm in size, slightly raised, and do not blanch with pressure. These skin lesions are best classified as which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythema refers to the redness of skin, rather than a specific cutaneous lesion. It is caused by increased blood flow to the skin and therefore blanches with pressure, in contrast to this patient's lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Cherry hemangiomas are vascular lesions that commonly develop in older individuals. However, they are typically bright red (not violaceous), dome-shaped papules or macules that manifest on the trunk and upper extremities and would be less likely to develop suddenly and only on the lower extremities. Moreover, these lesions usually blanch with pressure.
Image Description:

Photograph of the skin (unknown location)

Two small erythematous papules with a reddish-purple appearance are visible in the center of the image.

C) CORRECT:

Palpable purpura are raised, violaceous lesions caused by bleeding from small vessels in the skin. Because blood leaks into the extracellular space, these lesions do not completely blanch with pressure (in contrast to telangiectasias). This patient's skin lesions and arthritis are likely caused by cryoglobulinemic vasculitis, in which cryoglobulin immune complexes are deposited in small vessel walls, causing inflammation.
Image Description:

Multiple, partially confluent, round circular maculae (purpura) can be seen on both lower legs and thighs.

This is a common cutaneous symptom of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Petechiae, like this patient's lesions, are violaceous, vascular, and do not blanch with pressure. However, petechiae are nonpalpable and smaller in size (< 3 mm according to the American Academy of Dermatology).
Image Description:

The lower leg displays numerous red spots, each about the size of a pinhead, that do not blanch or disappear when pressed. These are indicative of petechial hemorrhages related to thrombocytopenia.

E) INCORRECT:

Ecchymoses, like this patient's lesions, are violaceous, vascular, and do not blanch with pressure. However, ecchymoses are nonpalpable and larger in size (> 5 mm according to the American Academy of Dermatology).
Image Description:

Ecchymosis on the right thigh; 64 hours after a bite from a spider (of the Loxosceles genus).

F) INCORRECT:

Spider angiomas are often associated with liver cirrhosis, which can develop in patients with chronic hepatitis C infection. However, spider angiomas are nonpalpable, vascular lesions characterized by a central arteriole with multiple small vessels that radiate outward. In contrast to this patient's lesions, they typically manifest on the neck, shoulders, or chest and blanch with pressure.
Image Description:

A telangiectasia characterized by a vascular arcade branching out from a central arteriolar point. Spider angiomas can arise during childhood or pregnancy as well as in patients with liver disease or thyrotoxicosis.
questions.hint: Patients with chronic hepatitis C infection can develop cryoglobulinemia, which is characterized by deposition of immune complexes and subsequent vasculitis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of nail changes. She says that her nails look “so ugly” that she is afraid to show her hands in public. The changes began on the fourth finger of each hand before progressing to all of her fingers and toes. Treatment with terbinafine has provided no relief. During the same time, she has also noticed that she is perspiring more than usual. The patient has not had any fever, cough, or changes in bowel habits. Her menses occur at irregular 40- and 50-day intervals. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. She has a seizure disorder and a history of migraine headaches. Current medications are valproic acid and over-the-counter ibuprofen. She has followed a strict vegan diet since the age of 22 years. She is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 50 kg (110 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 147/63 mm Hg. Physical examination shows nonpitting plaques on the shins. Examination of the hands shows thickened nails with distal white discoloration. There is a distal separation of the nail plates of her fourth digits from the nail beds. There is no pain or swelling of the finger joints. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's nail changes?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic undernutrition from dietary restriction can result in menstrual irregularities and micronutrient deficiencies. Iron deficiency can result in nail changes, and severe anemia may lead to tachycardia and widened pulse pressure. However, nail changes due to iron deficiency include brittle nails and koilonychia rather than onycholysis. In addition, excessive sweating and nonpitting plaques on the shins are not typical features of either iron deficiency or undernutrition.

B) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis can cause nail changes (e.g., onycholysis, nail pitting, oil drop sign) and plaques on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. However, the menstrual irregularities and vasomotor features (e.g., excessive sweating, systolic hypertension) seen in this patient are not manifestations of psoriasis.
Image Description:

The middle finger shows numerous superficial, round depressions (nail pits; examples indicated by arrowheads) caused by deficient keratinization. Both the ring and the middle finger show distal separation of the nail plate (onycholysis; green overlay). The index finger appears mostly normal.

Nail pitting and onycholysis are typical features of psoriasis with nail involvement.

C) INCORRECT:

Valproic acid may cause onycholysis, but nonpitting plaques on the shins, menstrual changes, and vasomotor features (e.g., excessive sweating, systolic hypertension) are not common. Other adverse effects of valproic acid include hair loss, a pruritic rash (due to drug-induced hypersensitivity syndrome), weight gain, hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, gastrointestinal distress, and tremor.

D) CORRECT:

Nail changes (e.g., onycholysis) and hair loss are dermatological manifestations of hyperthyroidism as well as hypothyroidism. Excessive sweating, oligomenorrhea, tachycardia, and systolic hypertension (with widened pulse pressure) indicate that hyperthyroidism is the most likely cause of this patient's nail changes. The presence of pretibial myxedema (nonpitting plaques and/or nodules on the shins) indicates that this patient's hyperthyroidism is due to Graves disease. Patients with Graves disease can also develop nail clubbing due to thyroid acropachy in the late stages of the disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Menopause occurs in women 45–55 years of age and can cause episodic vasomotor symptoms (e.g., excessive sweating, tachycardia). Also, during the menopausal transition, menses become irregular and decrease in frequency. However, this patient has onycholysis and nonpitting plaques, which are not features of menopause.
questions.hint: Thickened nails with distal white discoloration and separation of the nail plate are consistent with onycholysis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of a pruritic rash on the cubital fossae of the upper extremities. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. A skin biopsy of the rash shows intraepidermal accumulation of edematous fluid and widening of intercellular spaces between keratinocytes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis vulgaris is a chronic pruritic skin condition that can affect the bilateral upper extremities and typically develops in adults 20–40 years of age, like this patient. However, psoriasis particularly affects the extensor surfaces such as the elbows rather than the cubital fossae. While spongiosis can also occur in psoriasis vulgaris, it is more characteristic of another condition. Furthermore, typical biopsy findings of psoriatic lesions such as hyperkeratosis (with thickening of the stratum spinosum and thinning of the stratum granulosum), parakeratosis, elongation of the rete ridge, and Munro microabscesses are absent.
Image Description:

Confluent erythematous plaques with silver-white scaling are visible on the extensor surface of the upper limb.

B) INCORRECT:

Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic skin condition that can affect the bilateral upper extremities. However, biopsy of pemphigus vulgaris lesions shows acantholysis, retention of basal keratinocytes (which characteristically resemble a row of tombstones), and deposition of IgG in the intercellular spaces of the epidermis. Additionally, pemphigus vulgaris is usually nonpruritic, it also affects the oral mucosa, and most often develops in adults 30–60 years of age.
Image Description:

Multiple ruptured blisters with surrounding erythema are visible. A single intact blister can be seen in the center of the image.

This finding is suggestive of pemphigus vulgaris, but histopathology is required to confirm the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus is a chronic pruritic skin condition that can affect the bilateral upper extremities (particularly the flexural surfaces of the wrists). However, biopsy of lichen planus lesions shows hypergranulosis, irregular acanthosis (which causes a “sawtooth” appearance), and lymphocytic infiltrates at the dermal-epidermal junction. Moreover, lichen planus is most common in adults 30–60 years of age.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left wrist

Multiple erythematous papules, which are partially confluent are visible on the flexor side of the wrist. The papules are polygonal in shape and appear to be slightly elevated.

This finding is characteristic of cutaneous lichen planus. as polygonal, pink, slightly elevated, sharply demarcated, and partially confluent and partially grouped.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic pruritic skin condition that can affect the bilateral upper extremities (particularly the elbows). Biopsy of dermatitis herpetiformis lesions shows deposits of IgA and formation of microabscesses at the tips of dermal papillae, which are not seen in this patient. Additionally, this condition is usually associated with celiac disease, which there is no reason to suspect in this patient.
Image Description:

There is an erythematous, grouped, papulovesicular rash with excoriations on the extensor surface of the shoulder.

This finding, in combination with pruritus, is consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis.

E) INCORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is a chronic skin condition that can affect the bilateral upper extremities, although the neck and axillae are more commonly involved. However, biopsy of acanthosis nigricans lesions shows epidermal hyperplasia (acanthosis), which is not seen in this patient. Additionally, this condition is usually associated with insulin resistance (e.g., from diabetes, obesity, or polycystic ovary syndrome) or visceral malignancy, and this patient has no signs or symptoms of either condition.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmented skin and hyperkeratosis are visible in this patient's left axilla. An erythematous patch is visible in between the hyperpigmented areas.

These findings are suggestive of acanthosis nigricans.

F) CORRECT:

Eczematous dermatitis is the umbrella term for multiple conditions with overlapping clinical and histopathological features, including atopic dermatitis and allergic contact dermatitis. Each type manifests as a pruritic, erythematous, maculopapular rash with occasional crusting, drainage of serous fluid, and vesicle or bulla formation. This patient's 5-month history of a rash on both arms suggests a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, a chronic condition that typically develops on flexural surfaces (e.g., the antecubital fossae) in childhood but that can also manifest in adulthood.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of the skin (H&E stain, high magnification)

Tissue layers from top to bottom:

1. Stratum lucidum
2. Stratum granulosum
3. Stratum spinosum
4. Stratum basale
5. Papillary dermis

The dermal/epidermal junction is visible in the center of the image (green dashed line). The interstitium between keratinocytes is dilated due to edema (examples in yellow overlay). Dermal papillae are filled with keratinocytes.
questions.hint: Fluid collections within the epidermis seen on histopathological examination indicate spongiosis.
